newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian gilt prices rise on bank rate cut.
newsitem.headline: Indian gilt prices rise on bank rate cut.

text.p: Prices of Indian government securities rose on Thursday following a cut in a key bank rate by the central bank but dealers said the rise was checked by high call money rates.
They said prices rose on expectations of a fall in interest rates, dealers said.

A one percentage point cut on Wednesday in the rate the central bank lends to banks is seen leading to a fall in bank lending rates. The central bank also announced a one percentage point cut in the maximum interest payable on deposits with maturities of 30 days up to one year.
Bankers said they will consider cuts in their prime lending rates over the next few days after consulting their respective boards of directors.

"Prices rose today in anticipation of a fall in interest rates in the near future," said a dealer at a state-run bank. "Most banks are expected to announce cuts in both deposit and lending rates in the next few days."
Dealers said prices rose around 20-25 paise in actively traded securities and would have risen further but for the high call money rates.
"Call money rates, being around 9-10 percent today, kept the price rise in check," said a dealer. "Otherwise prices would have risen further."
The 12.14 percent 2000 government of India stock rose to 101.64 rupees from Tuesday's 101 while the 13.05 percent 2007 improved to 102.50 from 102.40, dealers said.
The 12.59 percent 2004, auctioned by the central bank on Wednesday at par, started trading at 100.10 and rose to 100.30, dealers said.
Treasury bills maturing in September yielded 6.75-6.90 percent while April bills yielded 9.0 percent, dealers said.
Call money ended at 9.25-9.75 percent, marginally down from opening quotes of 9.25-10.0 percent, dealers said.
They said most of the day's trade was done between 9.25 and 9.75 percent.

Dealers said they expect call money rates to ease to around 6.0 percent after the Reserve Bank of India repurchases securities worth 51 billion rupees on Saturday when it reverses a repo auction held on June 23.
